revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.2.6)
revision.text:
'''Bord na gCon''' ({{IPA-ga|bˠoːɾˠd̪ˠ nə ɡon̪ˠ}}; in [[English language|English]], the '''Irish Greyhound Board'''), abbreviated as '''BnaC''', is an [[Republic of Ireland|Irish]] [[state-sponsored bodies of the Republic of Ireland|semi-state body]] charged with regulating and promoting [[Greyhound racing in Ireland]].<ref name="dast">{{cite web|url=http://www.arts-sport-tourism.gov.ie/sport/agencies/greyhound_board.html |title=Bord na gCon |work=Sport Agencies |publisher=Department of Arts, Sports and Tourism |accessdate=2008-07-17 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080414183049/http://www.arts-sport-tourism.gov.ie/sport/agencies/greyhound_board.html |archivedate=2008-04-14 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The board has been active in developing the sport in Ireland since its founding in 1958,
The Bord na gCon is a commercial semi-state body and reports to the [[Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.igb.ie/globalassets/report-pdfs/annual-reports/annual-report-final2014.pdf|title=2014 Annual Report|publisher=Irish Greyhound Board}}</ref>
== History == Bord na gCon was established under the Greyhound Industry Act of 1958 with a number of aims. The body was formed to regulate the industry, operate a [[parimutuel betting|tote]] betting system, licence and authorise each stadium, its officials, and its on-course [[bookmaker]]s, and promote the sport through advertising and prize grants.<ref name="dast" /> Bord na gCon received €14.5 million in state funding during 2007, but has been criticised for lacking government oversight.<ref name="indo">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/activities-of-greyhound-board-went-unsupervised-1421822.html|title=Activities of greyhound board 'went unsupervised'|last=Brennan|first=Michael|date=2008-06-27|publisher=Irish Independent|accessdate=2008-07-17}}</ref> Bord na gCon has been active in improving Ireland's greyhound stadia in recent years, and in 2007 announced a €28 million investment in its facilities in [[Limerick]] and [[Kilkenny]].<ref name="rte2">{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/other/2007/0724/greyhounds.html|title=Bord Na gCon announces €28m investment|date=2007-07-24|publisher=RTÉ News|accessdate=2008-07-17}}</ref>
The board has long had a comprehensive policy on doping in the sport, even including [[viagra]] on its list of banned substances.<ref name="guardian">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2001/jun/21/world.paulkelso?commentpage=1|title=Racetrack ban after Viagra gets greyhounds going|last=Kelso|first=Paul|date=2001-06-21|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=2008-07-17}}</ref> However, in 2006 Bord na gCon was imbued with controversy. A report illustrating that two dogs had tested positive for the banned substance [[Erythropoietin|EPO]] was not made public by the board, contrary to standard practice. Aidan Tynan, the board's CEO at the time, sent a letter to the Minister for Sport, [[John O'Donoghue (politician)|John O'Donoghue]], outlining his concern with the situation. He was then removed from his position by the board. A government report subsequently criticised the board for its actions,<ref name="indo2">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/revealed-the-dogdoping-secret-report-130213.html|title=Revealed: the dog-doping secret report|last=Corcoran|first=Jody|date=2006-05-14|publisher=Irish Independent|accessdate=2008-07-17}}</ref><ref name="rte">{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2006/0704/bordnagcon.html?rss|title=Govt to re-examine laws after Bord na gCon report|date=2006-07-04|publisher=RTÉ News|accessdate=2008-07-17}}</ref> and a 2008 report by the [[Comptroller and Auditor General]] found some irregularities in the board's accounts.<ref name="itimes">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2008/0611/breaking69.htm|title=Bord na gCon investigation published|last=Daily|first=Darina|date=2008-06-11|publisher=The Irish Times|accessdate=2008-07-17}}</ref>
== Stadia == Bord na gCon regulates all of Ireland's greyhound stadia. There are stadia in the following locations:<ref name="igb-stadia">{{cite web|url=http://www.igb.ie/|title=Home Page (see Stadia)|publisher=Irish Greyhound Board|accessdate=2008-07-17}}</ref>
{{Col-begin}} {{Col-2}} '''Connacht''' * [[Galway Sportsgrounds|Galway]]
'''Leinster''' * Dublin ([[Harold's Cross Stadium|Harolds Cross]]) * Dublin ([[Shelbourne Park]]) * [[Dundalk Stadium|Dundalk]] * [[Enniscorthy Greyhound Stadium|Enniscorthy]] * [[Kilkenny Greyhound Stadium|Kilkenny]] * [[Longford Greyhound Stadium|Longford]] * [[Mullingar Greyhound Stadium|Mullingar]] * [[Newbridge Greyhound Stadium|Newbridge]]
{{Col-2}} '''Munster'''
* [[Clonmel Greyhound Stadium|Clonmel]] * [[Curraheen Park|Cork]] * [[Limerick Greyhound Stadium|Limerick]] * [[Thurles Greyhound Stadium|Thurles]] * [[Kingdom Greyhound Stadium|Tralee]] * [[Kilcohan Park|Waterford]] * [[Youghal Greyhound Stadium|Youghal]]
'''Ulster'''
* [[Lifford Greyhound Stadium|Lifford]] {{Col-end}}
